element_texts.text:
Capt Geo. M. Templeton
32nd U.S.C.S
Capt. Geo.M. Templeton
32nd U.S.C. Troops
Fathers Address
David Templeton
Canonsburg
Washington Co.
Penna

POCKET DIARY 
FOR 
1865.
CONTAINING
A Blank Space for Every Day in the Year,
CALENDAR,
RATES OF POSTAGE, &C.
PUBLISHED ANNUALLY
FOR THE TRADE.
1865.

SUNDAY, JANUARY 1, 1865.
May I be enabled to spend this year to a better advantage than I did the last.
MONDAY 2
There was a reception at McEwen’s in honour of Colonel Fraser, but the Col did not make his appearance. I had an invitation but did not go.
TUESDAY 3
Had an invitation to and attended dinner at Dr Stewart’s. Bob returned on 15 days furlough last Saturday.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1865.
SUNDAY 8
MONDAY 9
Attended church at Mr. Bains and heard Rankin Johnson preach a very good sermon

FRIDAY, JANUARY 13, 1865.
SATURDAY 14
Saw Sergt. R. S. Nicholls went home.
SUNDAY 15
Attended church at Mr. French's church

TUESDAY, JANUARY 10, 1865.
WEDNESDAY 11
THURSDAY 12
Samuel & I went to Pitt. I got 20 days extension to my leave. They wanted me on court-martial, but I respectfully declined

THURSDAY, JANUARY 19, 1865.
went in sleigh to Wm. Martins
FRIDAY 20
Returned: attended Society (F.L)
SATURDAY 21
Received telegram from N.Y. that the Steamer would leave on the 25th.

MONDAY, JANUARY 16, 1865.
Went with Saml. to Marys
TUESDAY 17
WEDNESDAY 18
Returned home. Called at Robert Russell's

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 25, 1865.
Went to Capt Stinson's office on State St but could not get transportation on the "Fulton", as she was full a day or two ago.  Told me to come back tomorrow
THURSDAY 26
Got transportation on the "Matanzas" to sail tomorrow. On the way from Pitt. became acquainted with Mr WH Burt chief clerk C.D. 1st Div 17th a.c. from that city. A fine fellow
FRIDAY 27
Went on board but on account of our tow not being ready did not get off until day break of Saturday.  Found Dr Phillips & a Dr Daly of Bellverseon aboard Have 125 passengers mostly off.

SUNDAY, JANUARY 22, 1865.
Attended church at Mr. French's
MONDAY 23
Left home about 8 am. arrived in Pitt 12 1/2 P.M. left for N.Y. 9:30 P.M. arriving about 3 P.M. of Tuesday.  I have a kind of a presentment that I may not return
TUESDAY 24
I hope to arrive at the Regt in time to be present at the taking of Charleston. Am stopping at the Brandreth Hotel

TUESDAY, JANUARY 31, 1865.
In sight of land about 9 a.m. Arrived off the "light ship" about 4 P.M. Got a pilot off another vessel and got opposite the dock about 7 P.M.  No boarding officer came on board.
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 1
As we had a case of smallpox on board, we were afraid we would have to go into quarantine. But we did not and after being boarded, got off about 9 AM. Found that the Regt was at Edisto. 
THURSDAY 2
There are no boats running to Edisto so that I don't know when I shall have a chance to go to the Regt.  I learn that Easton is to be Capt. in the 103rd Regt. which is being raised here and of which Col Woodford is to be Col.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 28, 1865.
Got our tow of a cattle Schooner and made an early start.  It was awful cold, & we had not enough blankets to keep us warm.  It became very stormy towards night, and about dark a great many were sick
SUNDAY 29
Very sick: did not get our of my berth. The cable gave way and our schooner parted company with us.  We went back but could not get her in tow again.
MONDAY 30
Feel pretty well: get up and stay on deck almost all day:  Passed Hatteras about 4 A.M.  There is quite a change in the atmosphere since yesterday, it being quite warm

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1865.
Heard that the Regt had a brush and had been driven back.  No sign of getting there.  Capt Kelly promises to send the first boat going to Morris Island in to Edisto.
TUESDAY 7
Met Burt again; he had been to Beaufort & Pocotaligo trying to get to the 17th Army Corps, but could not as they are quite a ways from the latter place & no communication.  That Corps had a fight on Friday & lost 250 men. 
WEDNESDAY 8 
A very dull day. No steamer going to Edisto.  Saw General Potter but did not have an opportunity of speaking to him.  I was going to ask him what chance there was of going to Edisto.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1865.
I am boarding at the Port Royal House & have a cot at the Pro. Mars office by the kindness of Maj Thompson I find  Lts Berryman & Glidden here, having never joined the Regt.
SATURDAY 4
Went out to see Capt Ferguson of 25th Ohio.  Gave him the packages for W H Weller to be forwarded to him.  Met my old classmate Coulter who is 2nd Lt in 144 N.Y. Vols. 
SUNDAY 5
Spent most of my time in Maj Thompson's office. I think the Maj. is one of the best men I ever knew.  He knows almost every one, especially persons from Florida.

SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1865.
There only some 500 contrabands on the island yet. A boat brought 100 more last night; also the chaplain of the 33 US. and two other gentlemen one of whom preached in the afternoon. It was warm enough to be pleasant in the shade of one of our fine live oaks. 
MONDAY 13
The above named gentlemen say Hatch has driven the rebs across the "Ashepoo" and that Sherman has passed by "Branchville".  The contrabands by burning the grass off their fields have set other portions of the island on fire Was out burning the grass around a house in order to preserve it.
TUESDAY 14
Mr Clark the sutler from Morris Island came to the wharf with a schooner load of sutler goods.  Some of the contrabands seem to be suffering for want of food.  Mr Clark says the Regt had a fight on James, & have gone to "Bulls Bay"

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 9. 1865.
Steamer "Illinois" came in with mail.  There is a steamer going to Folly. Asked Capt Kelly to have it stop at Edisto.  Promised to do so. Went on board "Chas Houghton" Took mail. Express & 11 Convalescents.
FRIDAY 10
Started at midnight and arrived about 7 A.M. Found Cos A & E and sick of other cos. The others on an expedition towards Folly.  Several officers are left behind on account of sickness, among whom is Webb.
SATURDAY 11
This is a fine island and has been inhabited by a very wealthy class, judging by the mansions and improvements.  My tent is in a garden in front of one of the houses.  Capt. Crissey Smith & myself laid out a new camp on another plantation.

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1865.
Lieut. & myself with some men took a boat and went out hunting ducks. Saw a good many but they were shy did not shoot any. Landed and examined a house on Little Edisto. Found nothing but some corn fodder. In another house got some papers, among them a list of slaves to be sold.
SUNDAY 19
Spent part of the day in reading the Bible and looking over the constitution of the Pres. Church. Had inspection at 8 P.M. 10 men present, 2 with guns. National salutes are being fired in the distance as there has been no cannonading in the direction of Charleston. I guess Petersburg must be taken.
MONDAY 20
Comdr. Preble U.S.A. sends us word that Charleston was evacuated on the 17th and is now occupied by our forces. Hurrah, Hurrah, Hurrah. But this is a festive place to be, only 25 miles distant & yet not know of its capture until the fourth day afterward.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 15,1865.
Went on guard as officer of the day & guard; had charge of the picket & camp guard.  The homes here will not compare with those north, but the shrubbery gives them an air of richness. 
THURSDAY 16
Went in ambulance with three gentlemen who came up the other day to the "Enoch Dean" which was lying about 6 miles down the island.  It was a strange sight to see so many  contrabands just landed with their '"household gods" lying around.
FRIDAY 17
I hope the Regt will come back some time soon, as our ordnance Returns for 4th as 64 have not yet been made, and cannot be until they return.  I apprehend our pay will be stoped therefor. Took a scout with 3 men to upper end of island. Saw nothing out of the way except some unclear

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1864.
Lieut Pierce & myself took a boat and went down to the U.S. Ship of war St Louis. 19 Comdr Preble U.S.A. The comdr was going out to the supply ship Nass. on an invitation from him went along.  Saw Lt Fisher of Genl Gilman's Staff, he says Regt is in Charleston, Got papers of the 18th.
SATURDAY 25
We are talking of going in a row boat to Charleston, conclude to put it off until after muster.  Visited the Wm. Seabrook place the finest on the island.  On Thursday went with some others to a church near by to get honey out of the steeple, same one had the start of us. 
SUNDAY 26
Reading in the Bible and Saurin's sermons

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1865.
Was on picket last night, all quiet with the exception of one fellow firing about 1 a.m. heard something in the grass. Lieut Jenkins intends going to Beaufort to draw rations tomorrow.  The recurrence of the 22nd reminds me that I became intimately acquainted with Geary? on the night of that day.
WEDNESDAY 22
The Hosp. Stewart returned from Beaufort, with papers of the 15th. Says 32nd are said to be in Charleston.  They had a fight on the 9th on James Island.  Lost 5 K. & 40 W Col. slightly w. 2 years ago today did my first picketing on the Rappahannock
THURSDAY 23
There are any number of robins here now,  I suppose those of the north spend their winters in this latitude.  Lieut. Jenkins went to Beaufort to draw rations and forage for this detachment.

THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1865.
Capt Smith, Lt Pierce, Lt Berryman & myself took 8 men in the boat and started for Charleston via "Haulover Cut" & Kiawah River. Started about 2 P.M. and passed Rockville at 4, and camped 2 miles above at dark, intending to go through the cut in the morning.
FRIDAY 3
Started as soon as the fog would allow going further up "Bohicket Cr" but after going 7 miles concluded we could not find the cut & turned back, on the way saw a cut we thought must be the one, but went home arriving about 8 P.M.
SATURDAY 4
Saw some contrabands who told us where the cut was. With some officers went up the creek between Edisto & Little Edisto to see if there was a passage through to South Edisto River: found there was. Found 20 bush of corn in a house

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1865.
Lieut Jenkins returned, with Lt Thomas & some convalescents. of my co. Black, Freeman, Giles & Saddler.  Lt. "J" brings rations & a large mail.  Letter from home. Raining for the past day or two Thomas brings news that Wilmington is evacuated. 
TUESDAY 28
Was mustered for pay by Capt Crissey. 23 of Co "C" present. Most of the wounded on James Island were of Cos "C"&"H", Maj Thompson is Pro. Mar Genl of Dept- South & Capt Pratt Pro Mar H Head District
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 1
Capt. Smith was afraid to start for Charleston on account of the rain.  Capt Crissey & Lieut Pierce went down to the St Louis; no news.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 8, 1865.
Started at 7 am. arrived in the city soon after. went to Pro Mar office, could not learn where Regt was. Went to Genl Hatch's Hd Qrs. Genl Potter was there & his Brig. & our Regt would be in the city in the evening or next morning. By the politeness of a Capt of the 33rd us are stoping at the house of Rev. Dr. Forrest Pres Clergyman.
THURSDAY 9
Went out to the intrenchments twice but the Regt was not yet in. The works are light on this side of the city, stretching from one river to the other. It seems there are 13 guns mounted on Sumpter where we thought there were none.
FRIDAY 10
About 10AM found the Regt had landed on the Laurens St wharf. Joined them & found all well. Marched in the evening outside the intrenchments the boys singing "John Brown" while going through the city. They enjoyed it hugely

SUNDAY, MARCH 5, 1865.
Mr Alden the agent of Freedmen came with another gent complaining of two of Co A who were guards at his place of stealing $160 from a cont. Lt Jenkins investigated the matter and after a long troublesome trial found the guilty parties & recovered $16.50
MONDAY 6
Took a new start, having Lt Thomas in addition to those named before. After some trouble found the cut, which was about 15 ft wide, went through and camped in a house on Kiawah Island. Explored a large Reb earthwork on Johns Island at the mouth of the cut.
TUESDAY 7
Started at 7 a.m. arriving at Folly R into Lt House Inlet & from there to Lt House creek & from there into Chastn Harbor arriving at Ft Johnston at 6 P.M. Stayed in Reb Hd Qrs. inside the Fort. There 18 guns mounted on Ft Johnston one a 300 pdr.

TUESDAY, MARCH 14, 1865.
Received orders to be ready to go to Edisto at a moments notice: This we owe to General Potter, who thinks a great deal of the Regt. and wishes to get us in his District. He commands Beaufort, District.
WEDNESDAY 15
Was detailed at Brig Field off of the Dug? The different Regt of the Brig were reviewed by Brig Genl Seth Williams Inspr Genl U.S.A, on Grant's staff. Our Regt made a good appearance considering the circumstances
THURSDAY 16
Are awaiting transportation. There seems to be a disposition on the part of the authorities here to retain us, if they can do so. Lieuts Jameson & McKinney & Co F are detailed as Hd Qrs guard for Genl Hatch. Comdg North Dist.

SATURDAY, MARCH 11, 1865.
Camped at Rackersville waiting for something to turn up. Was Officer of the Day, and had the camp policed, which is a "big thing" in a new camp. Lt Easton has not yet recd his papers, but is looking for them every day.
SUNDAY 12
Was relieved of my duties as Officer of the Day by Capt. Smith. Lt Easton went to the city and attended church at one of the churches where a delegate of the Christian Com preached.
MONDAY 13
Went to the city. The people seem very docile, and I not yet heard of any lady "spitting in anyone's face", or exhibiting their aversion to the Union. The fireeaters have left the city

MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1865.
Peache trees and peas are in blossom, and the spring is very late. The inhabitants say white people cannot live here after the first of May. They all go into the city then. I don't know how this is.
TUESDAY 21
Went out with the "Patrol" as far as the 6 mile House. The country is wild in many places. In the evening three ladies came in: two of them on the hunt of their husbands as it was after hours for passing. I retained them until morning. Gave them my room & blankets. Sleeping myself on the porch.
WEDNESDAY 22
Was relieved. Feel very sleepy and tired. A large number of Senators were on a visit to the city yesterday. On Monday Genl Saxton had a large procession of contrabands marching through the city, in honor of "Freedom"

FRIDAY, MARCH 17, 1865.
Major Thompson & the Misses Twitchell of Stoney called at Hd Qrs. The Maj is Provost War Genl of the Dept. Lieut Geise of our Regt. has gone as a 1st Lieut in 54th N.Y. Lieuts Easton & Brunning? left yesterday for their new Regiment.
SATURDAY 18
The Regt was inspected by Capt Samson of Genl Hatch's staff. There were only some 150 out, a number being on fatigue, & those out were mostly recruits & men who never drill. After inspection, we had one of the most bungling drills I ever saw.
SUNDAY 19
With 2 other officers was detailed on picket. Had my quarters at the 4 mile house on the state road My duties are to stop & examine passes of persons going wither way. Some few whites and numbers of blacks are coming inside the lines

SUNDAY, MARCH, 26, 1865.
Worked hard all day at ordnance return & muster Roll. I regreted the necessity, but we think we will not stay here but a few days longer. If the muster Rolls are not made how many families will suffer for want of the soldiers pay?
MONDAY 27
Moved camp inside the intrenchment: the officers quartering in a house. Finished everything but about an hours work & would have finished had I not spilled a bottle of ink on a finished Roll. Corpl Allan says Esqr Marrick of Wash Co is down town & would be glad to see me.
TUESDAY 28
The Adjt & Lieut Easton came from H.H. They could not get to Ed. Lt E is to be 2nd Capt. Was sorry I dod not bring his things from Edisto, but thought he would be there. He and I sat up very late marking Returns &c. Got our business all straightened up.

THURSDAY, MARCH 23, 1865.
Genl. Potter has made arrangements to have the comdg officers of Cos go to Edisto for Co. papers. Go in "Chas Houghton" run in to Stone too late to get across the bar before dark. There are rumors that we are going on another expedition perhaps to Florida.
FRIDAY 24
Arrived at Edisto 11A.M. Found Mrs Webb had arrived a few days before, had orders from Col. B. to take Lt W with me to Charleston. Dr Mason remains instead of Dr Wight Mr Hall the Sutler has arrived at Edisto & his partner is going to the Regt with us.
SATURDAY 25
Left Edisto 4.30 AM arriving in camp at Charleston at 10.30 Brought 14 of Co. "C" & about 60 of the Regt, who had been at Edisto. In the afternoon the papers & books arrived in camp & we commenced immediately.

SATURDAY, APRIL 1, 1865.
Drilled skirmishing drill. The Col returned bringing 87 men belonging to Cos now here. Late at night recd orders for 4 companies to go with the expedition. Expect to go Georgetown way.
SUNDAY 2
Orders were changed so that the eight companies are going about three P.M. marched the three cos. first intending to go down to the wharf, music playing. The men marched very well. Went on the Str "Canonicus" Later the col & other cos came
MONDAY 3
Sailed at daylight and about 10 am passed Cape Romain, about 2 P.M. landed at Georgetown S.C. camped outside of town. Found 25 & 107 Ohio, 157 N.Y. 54 Mass. 102 U.S. orders to be ready to move at an hours notice.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 29, 1865
The Col. Adjt & Lt Easton went to Edisto on the Charles Houghton. Leaving me in command. Recd. a large mail yesterday. Bad news from home.
THURSDAY 30
The Col. did not get off until early this morning.
FRIDAY 31
Drilled the company in skirmishing. It is something new and the boys take an interest in it.

FRIDAY, APRIL 7, 1865.
Was sent with 20 men to forage had to march very fast to get ahead, had 6 of the 20 when I stoped to commence foraging Got 6 horses 1 wagon & 1 cart, 60 hams, 50 sides, flour, meal, molasses, sweet potatoes, poultry, and burned 30 bales of cotton
SATURDAY 8
Our Regt in advance. My comp. advance guard. Reached Manning in the evening The cavalry had stoped having had a man killed. Went ahead but the Johns had left. Camped and at 12 P.M. broke camp & crossed the marsh and waited until morning.
SUNDAY 9
Marched 13 miles before dinner Rebs made a stand at the mill Pond 3 miles from Sumterville, flanked their right capturing all their cannon (2) & killing 1 capt & 1 Lt and killing & wounding some men, lost 26 of the 1st Brigade Advanced to Sumpterville.

TUESDAY, APRIL 4, 1865.
Laid in camp all day drilled the company in skirmish drill. Co. C. is on the right of the Battallion, and will perhaps have some skirmishing to do. Geotown is a small place not as large as can-, but has done a large lumber trade
WEDNESDAY 5
Started at 8 1/2 a.m. 32 in advance of 2nd Brig. which is composed of 32nd 54. 102? comdg by Col. Hartwell, 54 Mass. Marched 17 miles on the centre road through a desolate pine barren, only 3 houses on the way, one of which had chickens &c.
THURSDAY 6
Marched at 7 am marching 18 miles, had quite a lot of foraging during the day. Lt McKinney went out, and sent it in, under charge of a Corpl. but some offiver of the 157 took it from him. The Country somewhat better than yesterday.

THURSDAY, APRIL 13, 1865.
Arrived at Wrights Bluff about 1 P.M. Passed some of the finest plantations on the way that I have seen. About 1000 contrabands joined us on the march. Not enough boats to take our charge. Col B. sends to Genl Potter for orders.
FRIDAY 14
I and two companies start as guard to wagon trains going back with rations. Meet the cavalry 12 miles out and they take charge. Start back but receive orders from Col B. to on as he is coming. Camp for the night at Half way swamp.
SATURDAY 15
The remainder of the Regt came up about midnight, and the entire command marched at daylight arriving at Manchester at noon & the Division soon after. The Div. marched soon after, and met the Johnies in a short time. 25 Div lost 6. Our Regt was sent to the right to flank, did so.

MONDAY, APRIL 10, 1865.
Took a stroll through town, it is quite a pretty place. At 11 1/2 our Regt marched to Mayesville 10 miles on the Wilmington R.R. burned the depot & train of cars. About 30 rebs were there but left when we came up. I was out skirmishing & tried to get a shot at them but after following a mile could not.
TUESDAY 11
Returned from Mayesville yesterday as soon as possible arriving 10 P.M. Burned on the way back a tresle bridge 500 yds long. Marched at 6 am. went 2 miles beyond Manchester 15 miles. Are near the waters. The boats are near.
WEDNESDAY 12
Started late int he forenoon in charge of the wagon train and contrabands for wrights Bluff arriving at Half way swamp at 9 P.M. Have about 3000 contrabands of all sizes, ages & both sexes. They all seem glad to get away.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 19, 1865.
Skirmished all the way to Big Rafting Cr. 102 & Rt wing 32 in my charge flanked them on the left. they opened on us with 2 cannon but had to leave. 102 lost 4. 32nd one. Col. B & left wing & 107 Ohio found 2 locomotives & 43 cars on R.R. Camped near Manchester. The rebs on the dead run.
THURSDAY 20
Col Baird came in about 3 am. Had it not been so dark he could have burned a long train on tresle work 1St Brig. burned it consisting of 17 engines & 152 cars.loaded with merchandise, ammunition & provisions. Rested all day: the first since starting.
FRIDAY 21
Marched at daylight and stoped for dinner at or near Fulton P.O. while resting a flag of truce came in with news that a cessation of hostilities had been agreed upon between Genls Sherman & Johnson. Genl Young comdg red forces says he will not follow us. Genl Potter says he will return to Gaston not foraging

SUNDAY, APRIL 16, 1865.
Co. "C." skirmished with the rebs. yesterday, when making the flank movement marched towards Camden. 102nd skirmishing all the way. In the evening 32nd was sent to flank Co. "C". as skirmishers killed one & captured one. Camped at BradfordSprings P.O. There was a Female Seminary near here but has been burned.
MONDAY 17
The 32nd were Rearguard. Col Hallowell being sick Col Baird was in command of the Brigade. All but one co. were taken up to help flank a position. Cavalry attacked the rear guard. Expected a fight at Camden, but walked in about 6 P.M. The cars that we were after have gone down the road.
TUESDAY 18
Marched on the direct road towards Manchester. 32nd in advance C K & G as skirmishers. Drove the rebs until we came to Swift Co. where they were entrenched in force. Had some very narrow escapes. 54th Mass. flanked unclear when we crossed & they opened with artillery on us.

TUESDAY, APRIL 25, 1865.
Our Brig in advance. Make a start for Geotown at 6. am. make 15 miles again 10 am. here found rations which had been sent from Geo'town, arrive in G. at 5 P.M. 24 miles. Hear that Capt Crissey has been before a board of examiners.
WEDNESDAY 26
Went into our old camp ground last night, and I suppose are waiting for transportation to Charleston. The news of the assassination of Pres. Lincoln is confirmed, with the addition of Sec Seward & sons to the list of casualties
THURSDAY 27
Was officer of the day. Commenced work on the Muster Rolls. 1/2 hour guns were fired yesterday on account of the death of the President. Receive orders to go to Charleston in the morning

SATURDAY, APRIL 22, 1865.
Had dinner near Wrights Bluff while there heard that Genl Lee and army had been captured. Hurrah! If this truce results in peace Glory be to God in the Highest, for the army is tired and willing to accept an honorable peace.
SUNDAY 23
While marching along heard President Lincoln had been assassinated: it is not generally believed. Camped for the night near Murray's Ferry. expected the boats to be there but no rations until we get to Geotown is the cry.
MONDAY 24
Marched early & had a long days march. Rstered? corn to the men, which they parched and eat. Heard one say "They have given is our corn now they must carry us down

MONDAY, MAY 1, 1865.
Making out Muster Rolls. Have strawberries and peas in abundance.
TUESDAY 2
Finished the Muster Rolls. General Sherman is in the city.
WEDNESDAY 3
The Regt. Received orders to report to comdg. officer at Beaufort.

FRIDAY, APRIL 28, 1865.
Embark on the Savannah, and leave the wharf about 8 am. in tow of the Canonieur arriving at C. before Sundown. Find the adjutant's squad of sick on the wharf on their way to Edisto. They do not go
SATURDAY 29
March out to a lot near the Entrenchments inside & near our old camping ground.
SUNDAY 30
Were mustered for pay. Capt. Parker & Lieut Webb go to Edisto for Camp & garrison equipage.

SUNDAY, MAY 7, 1865.
Embark on the Savannah, get started about nine o'clock. The sea quite rough. The Capt. considerably alarmed. Get into Hilton Head sometime during the night.
MONDAY 8
After reporting to the Adjt Genl. procede to Beaufort arriving about noon, and find our camp to be near the town.
TUESDAY 9
Genl Potter is in command of the District. There is talk that this & H.H. Dist are to be united, & Genl P go to the Head. In which case Col B. will be post commander.

THURSDAY, MAY 4, 1865.
Marched down to the wharf and put the Regt. in a large ware house. Awaiting transportation. Turned in 5 unserviceable E.K.? Muskets.
FRIDAY 5
Still awaiting transportation.
SATURDAY 6
The Colonel takes the principal portion of the baggage and Co "G" and goes on the unclear "Mariah"; I am to follow. See Ensign Neil & procure transportation on the Savannah

SATURDAY, MAY 13, 1865.
Had the regular "monthly Inspection" by Captain Tracy. 26th U.S.C.T. The Regt does not look as well as it should.
SUNDAY 14
Had the Regular Inspection. In the afternoon, the troop attended down town to hear Sec. Chase, Rev. Dr Fuller and others make some remarks to the colored people.
MONDAY 15
Had Battallion Drill. The first I ever had command of.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 10, 1865.
Was Genl. Field officer of the Day. Have two horses furnished. Have a fine ride.
THURSDAY 11
Had a Battallion Drill, got along very well.
FRIDAY 12
Col. Baird is Post Comdr, which leaves me in comd. of the Regt.

FRIDAY, MAY 19, 1865.
Lieut. Webb went to Edisto with Lt Jenkins. Capt. Smith put in an application for a leave of absence. Col. Baird takes his Head Qrs at the house formerly occupied as an officer's Hospital.
SATURDAY 20
Captain Crissey forwards an application for a leave of absence. Lieut. Eaton is quite sick. Ly Pollock reported yesterday for duty.
SUNDAY 21
Some preacher came the other day and made arrangements to have church, but he has not made his appearance.

TUESDAY, MAY 16, 1865
Captain Tracy inspected the unserviceable ordnance of the Regt. The 26th U.S.C.T. have gone out into the country, to protect the citizens. Jeff Davis capsized & at the Head Hurrah.
WEDNESDAY 17
Davis & Family, Genls Wheeler & Basil Duke & staff, C.C. Clay Stephens and many others have been captured and were sent north yesterday. I hope they may be hanged.
THURSDAY 18
Maj. Thompson & the MissesTwitchell? came up last eve. Capt Crissey & Lt Jenkins came from Edisto. Dr Parks Relieved and Dr - assigned in his stead Capt. B. is not going to come and take comd of Regt.

THURSDAY, MAY 25, 1865.
Lieut Eddy & Co "C" were sent to Lemon Island on Broad River to drive away some guerillas that were said to have been there last night.
FRIDAY 26
Received our mail at last.
SATURDAY 27
Have orders for the recall of Lt Eddy & party as there seems to have been no ground for the alarm

MONDAY, MAY 22, 1865.
The details from the Regt. are so heavy that we cannot get out enough to make a battallion drill
TUESDAY 23
Lieut, McKinney & 20 men were sent to Port Royal Ferry on Sabbath to do the picket duty there & prevent contrabands from crossing over to the main land.
WEDNESDAY 24
Our mail which should have been here 4 days ago, has gone on a visit to Charleston, causing gnashing of teeth by some.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 31, 1865.
The court could not meet on account of the absence of Lt Col Rice the president.
THURSDAY, JUNE 1
Court met but there were not a quorum present.  Adjourned to Saturday. This is the Presidents Fast Day.  There is a meeting of contrabands, & Genl Saxton addressing them.
FRIDAY 2
Reading most of the time. A board has been convened for examining all officers.  Capts Crissey & Smith & Lieuts Rice & McGinley went north on leave.

SUNDAY, MAY 28, 1865.
MONDAY 29
Took our guns and accroutrements that were condemned up: are going to send them to the Head tomorrow.
TUESDAY 30
Received a detail as a member of a court martial to meet in this town.

TUESDAY, JUNE 6, 1865.
The eight companies were paid by Maj. Smith. The men all went up afterwards & paid the sutler what they owed him.
WEDNESDAY 7
Went out to Port Royal Ferry, to pay Dutton & [unclear] their money but they had just gone out in the woods, and did not come back while I was there.
THURSDAY 8
Went down to Port Royal on Hilton Head, got quarters at Provost Martials office Lieut Dodge being sick could not attend. No quorum.

SATURDAY JUNE 3, 1865. 
Court met but there being only 4 members detailed it is not a legal court.  Had another off. appointed, which was Lt Webb but as he is at Edisto recommended that they appoint another.
SUNDAY 4
Lt. McKinney was appointed on Court Martial. The pay Rolls were sent up. Will be paid tomorrow.
MONDAY 5
Maj Smith came up on the evening boat, but did not get ready to pay off. no mail came by the Fulton. Court met & finished one case.  Adjourned to meet at Hilton's Head on Thursday.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1865.
A little better
TUESDAY 13 
Although not on the sick list I have not resumed command of the Regt.
WEDNESDAY 14

FRIDAY, JUNE 9, 1865.
Tried one case and commenced another.  There seems to be quite a stir among officers anticipating the examination.
SATURDAY 10
Feel very unwell. Got on the boat about 3 PM intending to come up but it did not start until about 9 PM.  Just as much as I could do to get to my quarters
SUNDAY 11
Feel quite sick.

SUNDAY, JUNE 18, 1865.
Attended church in the evening. Heard Mr Harris Post Chaplain preach
MONDAY 19
The court was adjourned to meet today at Beaufort but was notified that we should meet at H. Head to reconsider our action in former cases
TUESDAY 20
The 144 N.Y. expected to be mustered out and go last boat, but they are now being examined by the board and will go home next boat.

THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1865.
Assumed command of the Regt.
FRIDAY 16
Joshua Gibbs and three others of the Co discharged.
SATURDAY 17
Some 19 of the Regt who were discharged at the Hospital had their discharges taken from them after they had gone on board the Beaufort boat

SATURDAY, JUNE 24, 1865.
Nothing new.
SUNDAY 25
Read in the Bible
MONDAY 26
Lieut Branigan came up to the Regt. to see his old friends.

WEDNESDAY JUNE 21, 1865.
Lieut Easton came up on Sabbath and went down on Monday. I can't get over calling him Lieut
THURSDAY 22
The Regiment was inspected by Capt Tracy. He expressed himself pleased with the progress they had made.
FRIDAY 23
Am studying up my tactics somewhat. Have a recitation by company officers

FRIDAY, JUNE 30, 1865.
Are awaiting further orders
SATURDAY, JULY 1
Still waiting 
SUNDAY 2
Received an order about 9 AM to go as soon as possible. Got most of the baggage down & sent three Cos with it Capt Parker in command.

TUESDAY, JUNE 27, 1865.
Lieut Jenkins came down from Edisto. The board of Examiners is said to be disolved on account of Genl Potter going north on next Boat & Maj Plasket? on this one.
WEDNESDAY 28
Commenced on the Muster Rolls.
THURSDAY 29
Received a telegram to have the Regt in readyness to embark for Hilton Head at once.  I am sorry that we go there. I fear we may have too much fatigue.

THURSDAY, JULY 6, 1865.
A very high fever
FRIDAY 7
About the same
SATURDAY 8
Better

MONDAY, JULY 3, 1865.
Arrived with other Companies at Hilton Head about 4 P.M. Went into camp inside intrenchments
TUESDAY 4
Was detailed on a unclear of administration and met at post Hd Qrs. Don't feel well. A white & Black picknick and fireworks in the evening.
WEDNESDAY 5
Was unable to leave my bed. Have a high fever.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 12, 1865.
Am quite well again.
THURSDAY 13
Was detailed on the examining board of Maj Lutor.
FRIDAY 14
Was detailed along with the other members of the other board to examine officers of the 26th USCS for promotion.

SUNDAY, JULY 9, 1865.
MONDAY 10
TUESDAY 11
writing vertically across left side of page
During sometime along about here the officers of the Regt were examined befor the board consisting of Col Baird Col Howard & Maj Lutor.

TUESDAY, JULY 18, 1865.
Examined all the officers of 26th that could be present. The Major and Capt Dyer were examined for the vacant Lt Colonelcy.
WEDNESDAY 19
Came down to Hilton Head intending to return Friday.
THURSDAY 20
Nothing new

SATURDAY, JULY 15, 1865.
Nothing new. I might state that the Companies at Edisto joined the Regt after we arrived here.
SUNDAY 16
Col B & I went to Beaufort not being able to get a boat to go in time for the board tomorrow.
MONDAY 17
The board examined about half the officers of the 26th USCS.

MONDAY, JULY 24, 1865.
Still bad
TUESDAY 25
The fever is broken but don't seem to get well.
WEDNESDAY 26
A little better

FRIDAY, JULY 21, 1865.
Postponed going to Beaufort until Monday. Went to bed in good health last night. Couldn't get up this morning on account of chills.
SATURDAY 22
Have a very high fever.
SUNDAY 23
Quite bad

SUNDAY, JULY 30, 1865.
Nothing new
MONDAY 31
Went down town and got paid up to June 30th $609.13
TUESDAY, AUGUST 1
Got another months pay $154.50

THURSDAY, JULY 27, 1865.
Ditto.
FRIDAY 28
Lieut Eaton & Hetfield went north. Got up in the morning and walked around some
SATURDAY 29
Was up all day

SATURDAY, AUGUST 5, 1865.
Nothing new
SUNDAY 6
Mail came in Recd two letters
MONDAY 7
Genl. Gillmore receives instructions to muster out all northern colored Regts but to retain the contrabands until further orders.

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 2, 1865.
Rumors of muster out 21st & 26th U.S. unclear have been ordered to make out their rolls.
THURSDAY 3
Genl. Gillmore recommends to the war Dept that all colored Regts be mustered out.
FRIDAY 4
We are going to have three steamers between here & New York and a mail every 5 or 6 days.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 11, 1865.
Quite bad.
SATURDAY 12
Ditto
Lieutenant McKinney mustered as 1st Lieut
SUNDAY 13
Better. Capt Stores came back from leave.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 8, 1865.
Went over to the Line of battleship New Hampshire, with Lieut Thomas. The Regt is to be mustered out immediately. read our muster out rolls.
WEDNESDAY 9
Had quite a day of reading.
THURSDAY 10
Another attack of fever.

THURSDAY, AUGUST 17, 1865.
Ditto.
FRIDAY 18
Learn that we have to make another roll six in all. Talk of going next Tuesday.
SATURDAY 19
Took one roll & Clothing book down & compared them.

MONDAY, AUGUST 14, 1865.
Was up part of the time and with Lt Thomas started a roll. Capt Easton came down.
TUESDAY 15
Went to work writing on the rolls.
WEDNESDAY 16
Hard at work, as I am far behind, but if I have my health am determined not to be the last in finishing my rolls

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 23, 1865.
Quite quiet since the right wing left
THURSDAY 24
Received orders to get ready to go immediately on the Str Genl Meigs with three companies
FRIDAY 25
Cos C E & K went on board about noon & put to sea at 3 PM Capt Stores was detained on Court martial

SUNDAY, AUGUST 20, 1865.
Finished the rolls in the forenoon. Dr - Pres Hospital chaplain preached to the Regt.
MONDAY 21
Learn that only five companies are going tomorrow & I am not one of them.
TUESDAY 22
Cos A D. F G & I. under Lt Col Thompson left me on the McClellan. They took drum Corps & both flags but I went on board & brought one away

TUESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1865.
Arrive off the coast of Maryland and in the evening at the Delaware Breakwater
WEDNESDAY 30
Arrive in the city about 10 AM and after reporting go to camp Cadwalader. Met McGurley. The other Cos have already been mustered out & paid off.
THURSDAY 31
The Detachment was paid off and all the men left for their homes.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 26, 1865.
Quite rough and most of us quite sick
SUNDAY 27
Some better
MONDAY 28
Quite well again

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1865.
Left on the 11.10 train last night and arrive at Pittsburg at 2.30 P.M.
TUESDAY 5
Saw Col Glenn Capt Slagle Lts Dalglish & Snodgrass, Nicholls, Calohan Batton & about 20 of the old company.
WEDNESDAY 6
Arrive in Canonsburg on the stage

FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1865.
Busy making out my returns. The remaining two companies under Col Baird arrived. I moved down into the city.
SATURDAY 2
Receive my pay Saw Stock? Graham.
SUNDAY 3
Went to hear Mr Barr Took Graham with me.

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1865.
SUNDAY 17
Newspaper clipping - text follows 
A correspondent, says a Boston paper, asks if it is possible to get the name of General Schimmelfennig, the commander of Charleston, into rhyme. Guess so :
"The gallant Dutchman, Schimmelfennig, 
Holds Charleston as he would a hen egg ;
He grabs the traitors by the ear,
And brings them to their lager beer.
We wish we had a million such men
As this bold rebel-hating Dutchman."
MONDAY 18

SUNDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1865.
Arrive in Baltimore at 7 AM
Attend Mr Bruce's church in the forenoon & afternoon
MONDAY 4
Report and find Col Baird and Capt Jameson. Cannot do anything until they find out about another case that is to be tried.
TUESDAY 5
Visited Washington Monument there are 228 steps in the stairway.

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1865.
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 1
Received a summons from Lt Col H H Bingham Judge Advocate to appear at Baltimore one the 4th inst as a witness in the case of Dr Wight.
SATURDAY 2
Leave C. and arrive in Pittsburgh via Steubenville RR. at 11 AM. Saw Harry McEwen on the way & ex Lt Corbin.
Leave Pitt. on the 3.30 train

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1865.
Called on Ben. unclear Justin and Hon Geo V Lawrence on the latter in reference to Reg Army, he has recommended Mr Atcheson of Wash. if he does not accept them me.
SUNDAY 10
Attended Dr Gurley's church. Col Baird is with me.
MONDAY 11
Came back to Baltimore Find Capts Plummer & Pierce Lt Pollock and Dr Mason.

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1865.
As we cannot do anything until after Thanksgiving with Col B & Capt J go to Gettysburg.
THURSDAY 7
Attend church in the morning & in the afternoon visit Cemetery & Battle field.
FRIDAY 8
Left Gettysburg at 8 AM arriving in Baltimore at 1 P.M. Report to Vol Bingham nothing new. Go to Washington in the evening. Put up at "Markhams"

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1865.
A new court has been convened with Bt Lt Geo Parsons 4th Arty. Judge Advocate. The case will be tried tomorrow.
WEDNESDAY 13
Gave a little testimony in regard to the case. They did not ask me about the thing I knew most about.
THURSDAY 14
Received some pay. We are allowed actual expenses and $3.00 per day while traveling and waiting.

THURSDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1865.
Received blank application for position in the Reg. Army from Hon. Geo. V. Lawrence and, after filling it up, forwarded it.
FRIDAY 22
SATURDAY 23
